												Definitely my favourite VR game yet! At the time of this review, Steam says I have a bit over an hour in the game, which seems weird to me because I definietly feel like its been at least twice that.Anyway, this is very fun! It becomes a lot more than just point and shoot, as the floaty squares shoot projectiles at you when you destroy them, and explode if you leave them for long enough without destroying them. You end up shooting and dodging, and constantly turning to check behind and above you for newly spawned floaty cubes (not really sure what to call them!)Every 5 waves you reach a sort of "checkpoint", ie when you die you can restart at that level - but only if you have reached that level at least once before.Once you reach wave 10 the dudes start to spawn. At first they seem less dangerous than the floaty cubes, as they move slowly and dont shoot at you, but I found them harder to hit, and if they reach you it is actually quite terrifying when they swing their sword in your face! It really gives motivation to improve your aim and shoot them before they get too close.This game is not yet perfect - my main complaint would be that the default aim is too low. It takes quite a bit of getting used to - I feel like I need to move my bowstring hand further down than I should just to get the arrow to fire straight and perpendicular to my body. As with almost all VR games at this point, it does feel like it could use a bit more work, but is still incredibly fun as it is at the moment.The constant doding, moving and shooting can get quite tiring. Whilst not especially fit, I'm in OK shape, and I find this game gets me fairly sweaty after playing for a while. I normally need to go take a shower straight after playing! I'm hoping this will help me get a bit fitter though, as it definitely feels like a mini-workout playing this.All in all a very fun game, and I definitely recommend you purchase it - unless, that is, you have the minimum amount of space to play in.This game requires you move around a bit, and initially I only had the minimum area to play in with my Vive, and I feared for my controllers with the amount I was smashing them into things (thankfully they are still fine).Once I managed to upgrade my space into a larger area it becamse a lot easier to play the game.You can still try play it in a tiny space, but its really hard and not too fun, so you might need to give this a miss if you are playing in a tiny space.

												You duck, you dodge, you draw, you lean to the side to avoid a bullet, you shoot. It's becoming frantic, they're getting close. Even my earbuds managed to get caught and pull out of my ears once. The game is fantastic, it's one of my favorite experiences so far. But it really shows off the limitations of the Vive's cabling. Maybe it's just me, maybe other people have a pulley or something to keep things organized.But in the first twenty minutes of any session, when there's slack in the cord and you're not sweaty, it's a ludicrously fun game. A few other games have "dodge" mechanics like this, but those other games make your hitbox so large that you can't dodge all that well (they have block mechanics too, usually). This one has no block, you can only dodge; and the dodging is very precise - you only need to move your head half a foot to the left and a bullet will miss you. It feels right, it's satisfying, and it's worth the experience.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												You duck, you dodge, you draw, you lean to the side to avoid a bullet, you shoot. It's becoming frantic, they're getting close. You're going so fast your arrows have literally lit on fire. You're hot and sweating, you're almost to the end of the wave. And then, as you pivot to take out a humming square that's about to shoot, your Vive's power connector yanks out of the box because you've been spinning around so much that the tether is all twisted. You lost.That was my biggest enemy in this game, stepping on the cord, getting the cord tangled, unplugging the cord because all the slack was taken up by twists. Even my earbuds managed to get caught and pull out of my ears once. The game is fantastic, it's one of my favorite experiences so far. But it really shows off the limitations of the Vive's cabling. Maybe it's just me, maybe other people have a pulley or something to keep things organized.But in the first twenty minutes of any session, when there's slack in the cord and you're not sweaty, it's a ludicrously fun game. A few other games have "dodge" mechanics like this, but those other games make your hitbox so large that you can't dodge all that well (they have block mechanics too, usually). This one has no block, you can only dodge; and the dodging is very precise - you only need to move your head half a foot to the left and a bullet will miss you. It feels right, it's satisfying, and it's worth the experience.

												While looking for new things to try on the Vive, I've heard *so* many comments of the form "This game doesn't look like much, but give it a try." Even though it requires a high-end PC and an $800 headset thingie, it somehow reminds me of some of the very first video games, in a very very good way. It's just pure gameplay. There's no gimmicks, no plot, no nothing, just you and a high score list, but the gameplay is so damn *fun* that that's all you care about.As (many) other reviews on the interwebs say, yes, it does in fact make you feel like a badass. When you duck underneath a cyber-samurai's sword swing while drawing back your bow to take out another one off to the side, yeah, you feel ridiculously cool. And that's because Holopoint just strips away everything and somehow makes you feel you're *there*. It is so viscerally satisfying.A couple of things that could impact your Vive's livelihood. First, after playing this for 15-20 minutes, I started to sweat a bit. Which hasn't come close to happening with any other VR thing I've played. Maybe a little bit with the (similarly simple but beautiful) Space Pirate Trainer, but not to this degree. So you might get some damp (and eventually stinky) Vive foam.Second, as a few other reviews point out, you move around a *lot* in this game. 			Holopoint is like if SuperHot had sex with Space Pirate Simulator and Geometry Wars is in the closet watching... ...but there's no slow motion and your only weapon is a bow and some arrows.		

Holopoint is like if SuperHot had sex with Space Pirate Simulator and Geometry Wars is in the closet watching… but there is no slow motion and you can only use a bow and arrow. Is that helpful? I think that describes this game pretty well after playing it for 50+ hours. At its heart it’s another wave based survival game that strongly prioritizes your own reactive movements above all else. Yes, it’s important to be accurate but you can miss an arrow here and there without the game ending. You yourself can only take two hits until it’s Game Over, so getting the Hell out of the way is a bit more important than landing your shots. That being said, I’d try to make every arrow count anyway as that’s pretty key for your hitting a new high score. Chasing after your high score is very addictive as no matter how low your score starts there is just something about knowing you’re a faster and a better virtual bowman than the dude you just toppled on the leaderboard. There is a downside: good luck not tangling your Vive’s cable. No, seriously, good luck. You’re going to need it. Based on how often enemies attack you from behind it would be a damn miracle for your not to have a horrifically tangled mess by the time you’re done with an intense play session. Still, even with that negative, I’d urge you to buy Holopoint if any of this sounds vaguely interesting. It may not be the best bow and arrow simulator on the Vive (though I intend to find out what is) but it sure does make you feel like a badass… perhaps more than any other game before it. I’d just probably do some stretches or something beforehand though, you don’t want to pull a hammy.

												The game is fun, but IMO the best part is that it is such great exercise. As other reviews have stated, you have to keep moving and ducking and reloading and firing all around and above you constantly. If you value aerobic exercise, would you rather plod away on a treadmill in a straight line, or have fun playing a competitive game? I know the answer for me: Holopoint!

Posted: April 9
												I purchased a VR system as a means of avoiding becoming sedentary after I started working from home (at computer all day).  Of all the games I purchased, Holopoint is probably the top for getting my heartrate up.  The first levels are very easy, just introducing you to the game.  Once you hit level 25 though (you can start a play session at any level you have reached in increments of 5) the game is surprisingly fast paced and tiring.When things get intense, I find myself crouched on the ground firing arrows and spinning on my heels like Legolas in LOTR movies.  The game is definitely better with a large play space and I highly encourage some kind of ceiling cable management system to keep the cords from getting tangled around your feet.  This is definitely a Room Scale game.  There is no front/back, the game takes place all around you and above you.My current plan is to add a weighted vest once I am able to beat the game, though I still can't seem to reach level 30.

Posted: February 25
												Warning: this game will give you a work out. All of the ducking and leaning and arm movements will leave you sweating and gasping for air if you're not in moderately good shape to begin with.With the warning out of the way, this game is addicting! It takes a little while to get the hang of shooting, but once you do you'll feel like a Samurai Neo. This is at the top of my personal "must own VR games".
